column4: how do I resize my LVM partitions? I want to shrink the / filesystem and make a separate /home partition, then upgrade to (reinstall) 64-bit ubuntu in /
Are you using any features of ext3 beyond journaling?
Extended attributes..which I guess ext2 can have too.
My overall question is based on that you need to resize the filesystem first, then you can use lvm tools to shrink the container.
And since you're wanting to resize /, you'll need to use a livecd/recovercd with a resizer.
I tried using GParted from the PartedMagic livecd, but it did not recognize the LVM partition
From a quick glance, it looks like partedmagic might not support lvm.
Ah..even futher: "GParted does not support logical volume management (LVM) at present, although this feature has been requested[3] by many users and may be implemented in a future release."
would the Kubuntu live CD work?
I'm not sure.  I don't know what files it includes.
Mount it and check if it has resize2fs.
I've used resize2fs in the past and it's worked fine.
If you go that approach, you'll want to resize your / down by some amount (say 1.5GB), shrink its container (by say 1GB), then resize again to enlarge to take up all the available space.
At least, that seems to be the recommended safest approach.
